title: I am 26. $60k student loans $30k in credit card and miscellaneous debt. Unemplyed. Exhausted all resources. Best options?
question: I have been unable to find a steady source of income. I have exhausted all my resources and have
answers: I agree with colleagues. You do not appear to have sufficient resources to propose a debt settlement. Cresit card and other miscellaneous debt dischargeable. Studne loans non-dischargeable. Consult BL counsel.
I agree with all of the other answers but would add that a bankruptcy will stay on your credit report for 10 years.

Your student loans are generally non-dischargeable in a bankruptcy proceeding unless you can prove that the repayment would be an undue hardship to you and your dependents, something that is very difficult to prove, especially at this point in your career. While $30,000 in credit card and other miscellaneous debt is not that substantial, when you put that on top of the $60,000, it becomes insurmountable. I would recommend that you meet with qualified counsel to discuss your options as filing a Chapter 7 may be your best option.

Put the credit issue out of your mind. Your credit is already trashed because of the student loans and credit card debt. A bankruptcy would actually HELP your credit.

You probably need to file bankruptcy. At a minimum, that off loads the credit card debt. However, until you start earning income, there really isn't much you can do with the student loans. I love when people "suggest" settlement...they tend to forget that it takes money to settle. The irony is that if the debtor actually has the resources to settle, they probably don't need to settle.

Meet with a bankruptcy. The strategy here (and I do this for many clients) is to file BK, offload what can be offloaded. That sets you up to have a fighting chance to deal with your student loans when you finally have the resources to do it. You probably should have done this many months or years ago. You probably could have saved your the resources you lost and saved your family whatever money they used to help you. Or, at least put those resources to better use.

Your CC debt likely could be discharged in BK, but student loans are a different matter. The general rule is they are not dischargeable, but there are some exceptions for hardship situations. Here is the so-called "Brunner Test":
The default judgment would still be a debt for student loans, which means in order to discharge them in bankruptcy you would need to file an adversary proceeding against the student loan company (reopening your bankruptcy), and establish the three elements of the very restrictive "Brunner Test":

1. Based upon your current income and expenses, you cannot maintain a minimal standard of living for yourself and your dependents if you are forced to repay your loans.
2. Your current financial situation is likely to continue for a big part of the repayment period.
3. You have made a good faith effort to repay your student loans.

Good luck

You probably want to consult a local bankruptcy attorney in your area. Bankruptcy will help you to discharge your credit cards debt, medical bills, etc. However, it will not discharge your liability to pay student loans. Best of luck.
